title.en: House of Prince Xiao of Liang
title.raw: 《梁孝王世家》 House of Prince Xiao of Liang

sentences.zh: 梁孝王武者，孝文皇帝子也，而與孝景帝同母。

translations.literal: Prince Xiao of Liang, Liu Wu, was a son of Emperor Xiaowen, and shared the same mother as Emperor Xiaojing.

sentences.zh: 母，竇太后也。

translations.literal: Their mother was Empress Dowager Dou.
Prince Xiao of Liang, Liu Wu, was a son of Emperor Xiaowen, and shared the same mother as Emperor Xiaojing. Their mother was Empress Dowager Dou.

sentences.zh: 孝文帝凡四男：長子曰太子，是為孝景帝；

translations.literal: Emperor Xiaowen had four sons altogether: the eldest son was the Crown Prince, who became Emperor Xiaojing;

sentences.zh: 次子武；

translations.literal: the second son was Wu;

sentences.zh: 次子參；

translations.literal: the third son was Shen;

sentences.zh: 次子勝。

translations.literal: the fourth son was Sheng.

sentences.zh: 孝文帝即位二年，以武為代王，以參為太原王，以勝為梁王。

translations.literal: Emperor Xiaowen ascended the throne in year 2, enfeoffing Wu as King of Dai, Shen as King of Taiyuan, Sheng as King of Liang.

sentences.zh: 二歲，徙代王為淮陽王。

translations.literal: Two years later, he transferred the King of Dai to be King of Huaiyang.

sentences.zh: 以代盡與太原王，號曰代王。

translations.literal: He gave all of Dai to the King of Taiyuan, who was then titled King of Dai.

sentences.zh: 參立十七年，孝文後二年卒，謚為孝王。

translations.literal: Shen reigned seventeen years, died in the second year after Xiaowen, posthumous title King Xiao.

sentences.zh: 子登嗣立，是為代共王。

translations.literal: His son Deng succeeded him, becoming King Gong of Dai.

sentences.zh: 立二十九年，元光二年卒。

translations.literal: He reigned twenty-nine years, died in Yuanguang year 2.

sentences.zh: 子義立，是為代王。

translations.literal: His son Yi succeeded him, becoming King of Dai.

sentences.zh: 十九年，漢廣關，以常山為限，而徙代王王清河。

translations.literal: Nineteen years later, Han expanded the passes, using Changshan as the boundary, and transferred the King of Dai to rule Qinghe.

sentences.zh: 清河王徙以元鼎三年也。

translations.literal: The King of Qinghe's transfer was in Yuanding year 3.

Emperor Xiaowen had four sons altogether: the eldest son was the Crown Prince, who became Emperor Xiaojing; the second son was Wu; the third son was Shen; the fourth son was Sheng. Emperor Xiaowen ascended the throne in year 2, enfeoffing Wu as King of Dai, Shen as King of Taiyuan, Sheng as King of Liang. Two years later, he transferred the King of Dai to be King of Huaiyang. He gave all of Dai to the King of Taiyuan, who was then titled King of Dai. Shen reigned seventeen years, died in the second year after Xiaowen, posthumous title King Xiao. His son Deng succeeded him, becoming King Gong of Dai. He reigned twenty-nine years, died in Yuanguang year 2. His son Yi succeeded him, becoming King of Dai. Nineteen years later, Han expanded the passes, using Changshan as the boundary, and transferred the King of Dai to rule Qinghe. The King of Qinghe's transfer was in Yuanding year 3.

sentences.zh: 初，武為淮陽王十年，而梁王勝卒，謚為梁懷王。

translations.literal: Initially, Wu served as King of Huaiyang for ten years, while the King of Liang Sheng died, posthumous title King Huai of Liang.

sentences.zh: 懷王最少子，愛幸異於他子。

translations.literal: King Huai was the youngest son, loved and favored differently from the other sons.

sentences.zh: 其明年，徙淮陽王武為梁王。

translations.literal: The next year, he transferred the King of Huaiyang Wu to be King of Liang.

sentences.zh: 梁王之初王梁，孝文帝之十二年也。

translations.literal: The King of Liang's first enfeoffment in Liang was in Emperor Xiaowen's twelfth year.

sentences.zh: 梁王自初王通歷已十一年矣。

translations.literal: The King of Liang, from his initial enfeoffment to now, had experienced eleven years.

Initially, Wu served as King of Huaiyang for ten years, while the King of Liang Sheng died, posthumous title King Huai of Liang. King Huai was the youngest son, loved and favored differently from the other sons. The next year, he transferred the King of Huaiyang Wu to be King of Liang. The King of Liang's first enfeoffment in Liang was in Emperor Xiaowen's twelfth year. The King of Liang, from his initial enfeoffment to now, had experienced eleven years.

sentences.zh: 梁王十四年，入朝。

translations.literal: In the King of Liang's fourteenth year, he entered court.

sentences.zh: 十七年，十八年，比年入朝，留，其明年，乃之國。

translations.literal: In years seventeen and eighteen, he entered court consecutively, remained, and only the next year returned to his fief.

sentences.zh: 二十一年，入朝。

translations.literal: In year twenty-one, he entered court.

sentences.zh: 二十二年，孝文帝崩。

translations.literal: In year twenty-two, Emperor Xiaowen passed away.

sentences.zh: 二十四年，入朝。

translations.literal: In year twenty-four, he entered court.

sentences.zh: 二十五年，復入朝。

translations.literal: In year twenty-five, he entered court again.

sentences.zh: 是時上未置太子也。

translations.literal: At this time the emperor had not yet established a crown prince.

sentences.zh: 上與梁王燕飲，嘗從容言曰：「千秋萬歲後傳於王。」

translations.literal: The emperor and the King of Liang were feasting, and once casually said: 'After a thousand autumns and ten thousand years I will pass it to the king.'

sentences.zh: 王辭謝。

translations.literal: The king declined politely.

sentences.zh: 雖知非至言，然心內喜。

translations.literal: Though he knew these were not serious words, in his heart he was inwardly pleased.

sentences.zh: 太后亦然。

translations.literal: The empress dowager was the same.

In the King of Liang's fourteenth year, he entered court. In years seventeen and eighteen, he entered court consecutively, remained, and only the next year returned to his fief. In year twenty-one, he entered court. In year twenty-two, Emperor Xiaowen passed away. In year twenty-four, he entered court. In year twenty-five, he entered court again. At this time the emperor had not yet established a crown prince. The emperor and the King of Liang were feasting, and once casually said: 'After a thousand autumns and ten thousand years I will pass it to the king.' The king declined politely. Though he knew these were not serious words, in his heart he was inwardly pleased. The empress dowager was the same.

sentences.zh: 其春，吳楚齊趙七國反。

translations.literal: That spring, Wu, Chu, Qi, and Zhao—the seven kingdoms—rebelled.

sentences.zh: 吳楚先擊梁棘壁，殺數萬人。

translations.literal: Wu and Chu first attacked Liang's Ji Wall, killing tens of thousands.

sentences.zh: 梁孝王城守睢陽，而使韓安國、張羽等為大將軍，以距吳楚。

translations.literal: Prince Xiao of Liang defended the city of Suiyang, and sent Han Anguo, Zhang Yu and others as grand generals to resist Wu and Chu.

sentences.zh: 吳楚以梁為限，不敢過而西，與太尉亞夫等相距三月。

translations.literal: Wu and Chu used Liang as their limit, dared not cross west, and confronted Grand Commandant Yafu and others for three months.

sentences.zh: 吳楚破，而梁所破殺虜略與漢中分。

translations.literal: Wu and Chu were defeated, and Liang's captured, killed, and plundered was shared equally with Han.

sentences.zh: 明年，漢立太子。

translations.literal: The next year, Han established the crown prince.

sentences.zh: 其後梁最親，有功，又為大國，居天下膏腴地。

translations.literal: Afterwards Liang was closest, had merit, was also a great kingdom, occupying the fertile lands of the realm.

sentences.zh: 地北界泰山，西至高陽，四十餘城，皆多大縣。

translations.literal: Its territory bordered Mount Tai in the north, reached Gaoyang in the west, over forty cities, all with many large counties.

That spring, Wu, Chu, Qi, and Zhao—the seven kingdoms—rebelled. Wu and Chu first attacked Liang's Ji Wall, killing tens of thousands. Prince Xiao of Liang defended the city of Suiyang, and sent Han Anguo, Zhang Yu and others as grand generals to resist Wu and Chu. Wu and Chu used Liang as their limit, dared not cross west, and confronted Grand Commandant Yafu and others for three months. Wu and Chu were defeated, and Liang's captured, killed, and plundered was shared equally with Han. The next year, Han established the crown prince. Afterwards Liang was closest, had merit, was also a great kingdom, occupying the fertile lands of the realm. Its territory bordered Mount Tai in the north, reached Gaoyang in the west, over forty cities, all with many large counties.

sentences.zh: 孝王，竇太后少子也，愛之，賞賜不可勝道。

translations.literal: Prince Xiao was Empress Dowager Dou's youngest son, she loved him, rewards and grants beyond counting.

sentences.zh: 於是孝王筑東苑，方三百餘里。

translations.literal: Thus Prince Xiao built the Eastern Park, covering over three hundred li square.

sentences.zh: 廣睢陽城七十里。

translations.literal: He expanded Suiyang city seventy li.

sentences.zh: 大治宮室，為複道，自宮連屬於平臺三十餘里。

translations.literal: He greatly constructed palaces, built covered walkways connecting from the palace to the Platform for over thirty li.

sentences.zh: 得賜天子旌旗，出從千乘萬騎。

translations.literal: He received the emperor's banners and flags as grants, went out followed by a thousand chariots and ten thousand cavalry.

sentences.zh: 東西馳獵，擬於天子。

translations.literal: He galloped hunting east and west, comparable to the Son of Heaven.

sentences.zh: 出言蹕，入言警。

translations.literal: When going out he used 'clear the way,' when entering he used 'be alert.'

sentences.zh: 招延四方豪桀，自山以東游說之士。

translations.literal: He recruited and welcomed heroes and outstanding men from the four directions, wandering persuaders from east of the mountains.

sentences.zh: 莫不畢至，齊人羊勝、公孫詭、鄒陽之屬。

translations.literal: None failed to arrive completely—men from Qi like Yang Sheng, Gongsun Gui, Zou Yang and such.

sentences.zh: 公孫詭多奇邪計，初見王，賜千金，官至中尉，梁號之曰公孫將軍，梁多作兵器弩弓矛數十萬，而府庫金錢且百巨萬，珠玉寶器多於京師。

translations.literal: Gongsun Gui had many strange and crooked schemes, first meeting the king, granted a thousand jin, office reaching Commandant of the Guards, Liang titled him General Gongsun, Liang made many weapons—crossbows, bows, spears—several tens of thousands, while the treasury had gold and cash nearly a hundred million, pearls, jade, and precious objects more than the capital.

Prince Xiao was Empress Dowager Dou's youngest son, she loved him, rewards and grants beyond counting. Thus Prince Xiao built the Eastern Park, covering over three hundred li square. He expanded Suiyang city seventy li. He greatly constructed palaces, built covered walkways connecting from the palace to the Platform for over thirty li. He received the emperor's banners and flags as grants, went out followed by a thousand chariots and ten thousand cavalry. He galloped hunting east and west, comparable to the Son of Heaven. When going out he used 'clear the way,' when entering he used 'be alert.' He recruited and welcomed heroes and outstanding men from the four directions, wandering persuaders from east of the mountains. None failed to arrive completely—men from Qi like Yang Sheng, Gongsun Gui, Zou Yang and such. Gongsun Gui had many strange and crooked schemes, first meeting the king, granted a thousand jin, office reaching Commandant of the Guards, Liang titled him General Gongsun, Liang made many weapons—crossbows, bows, spears—several tens of thousands, while the treasury had gold and cash nearly a hundred million, pearls, jade, and precious objects more than the capital.

sentences.zh: 二十九年十月，梁孝王入朝。

translations.literal: In year twenty-nine, tenth month, Prince Xiao of Liang entered court.

sentences.zh: 景帝使使持節乘輿駟馬，迎梁王於關下。

translations.literal: Emperor Jing sent envoys holding the tally with imperial chariot and four horses, to welcome the King of Liang at the pass.

sentences.zh: 既朝，上疏因留，以太后親故。

translations.literal: Having attended court, he submitted a memorial requesting to remain, because of the empress dowager's close relation.

sentences.zh: 王入則侍景帝同輦，出則同車游獵，射禽獸上林中。

translations.literal: When the king entered he served Emperor Jing in the same chariot, when going out they rode in the same carriage hunting, shooting birds and beasts in Shanglin Park.

sentences.zh: 梁之侍中、郎、謁者著籍引出入天子殿門，與漢宦官無異。

translations.literal: Liang's attendants-in-ordinary, gentlemen, and ushers were registered and led in and out of the Son of Heaven's palace gates, no different from Han eunuchs.

In year twenty-nine, tenth month, Prince Xiao of Liang entered court. Emperor Jing sent envoys holding the tally with imperial chariot and four horses, to welcome the King of Liang at the pass. Having attended court, he submitted a memorial requesting to remain, because of the empress dowager's close relation. When the king entered he served Emperor Jing in the same chariot, when going out they rode in the same carriage hunting, shooting birds and beasts in Shanglin Park. Liang's attendants-in-ordinary, gentlemen, and ushers were registered and led in and out of the Son of Heaven's palace gates, no different from Han eunuchs.

sentences.zh: 十一月，上廢栗太子，竇太后心欲以孝王為後嗣。

translations.literal: In the eleventh month, the emperor deposed Crown Prince Li, Empress Dowager Dou's heart wished to make Prince Xiao the successor.

sentences.zh: 大臣及袁盎等有所關說於景帝，竇太后義格，亦遂不復言以梁王為嗣事由此。

translations.literal: Ministers and Yuan Ang and others had discussions with Emperor Jing, Empress Dowager Dou's sense of righteousness blocked it, and thus no longer spoke of making the King of Liang successor—from this point.

sentences.zh: 以事秘，世莫知。

translations.literal: Because the matter was secret, the world did not know.

sentences.zh: 乃辭歸國。

translations.literal: So he took leave and returned home.

In the eleventh month, the emperor deposed Crown Prince Li, Empress Dowager Dou's heart wished to make Prince Xiao the successor. Ministers and Yuan Ang and others had discussions with Emperor Jing, Empress Dowager Dou's sense of righteousness blocked it, and thus no longer spoke of making the King of Liang successor—from this point. Because the matter was secret, the world did not know. So he took leave and returned home.

sentences.zh: 其夏四月，上立膠東王為太子。

translations.literal: That summer, fourth month, the emperor established the King of Jiaodong as crown prince.

sentences.zh: 梁王怨袁盎及議臣，乃與羊勝、公孫詭之屬陰使人刺殺袁盎及他議臣十餘人。

translations.literal: The King of Liang resented Yuan Ang and the discussing ministers, so secretly sent men with Yang Sheng, Gongsun Gui and others to assassinate Yuan Ang and more than ten other discussing ministers.

sentences.zh: 逐其賊，未得也。

translations.literal: They pursued the assassins, did not catch them.

sentences.zh: 於是天子意梁王，逐賊，果梁使之。

translations.literal: Thus the Son of Heaven suspected the King of Liang, pursuing the assassins—indeed it was Liang who sent them.

sentences.zh: 乃遣使冠蓋相望於道，覆按梁，捕公孫詭、羊勝。

translations.literal: Thus he sent envoys with coronets and canopies meeting each other on the road, to investigate Liang, arresting Gongsun Gui and Yang Sheng.

sentences.zh: 公孫詭、羊勝匿王後宮。

translations.literal: Gongsun Gui and Yang Sheng hid in the king's rear palace.

sentences.zh: 使者責二千石急，梁相軒丘豹及內史韓安國進諫王，王乃令勝、詭皆自殺，出之。

translations.literal: The envoys pressed the two thousand shi officials urgently, Liang chancellor Xuanqiu Bao and Chamberlain Han Anguo advanced to remonstrate with the king, the king then ordered Sheng and Gui both to commit suicide, and handed them out.

sentences.zh: 上由此怨望於梁王。

translations.literal: The emperor from this resented and distrusted the King of Liang.

sentences.zh: 梁王恐，乃使韓安國因長公主謝罪太后，然后得釋。

translations.literal: The King of Liang feared, so sent Han Anguo through the eldest princess to apologize to the empress dowager, then was released.

That summer, fourth month, the emperor established the King of Jiaodong as crown prince. The King of Liang resented Yuan Ang and the discussing ministers, so secretly sent men with Yang Sheng, Gongsun Gui and others to assassinate Yuan Ang and more than ten other discussing ministers. They pursued the assassins, did not catch them. Thus the Son of Heaven suspected the King of Liang, pursuing the assassins—indeed it was Liang who sent them. Thus he sent envoys with coronets and canopies meeting each other on the road, to investigate Liang, arresting Gongsun Gui and Yang Sheng. Gongsun Gui and Yang Sheng hid in the king's rear palace. The envoys pressed the two thousand shi officials urgently, Liang chancellor Xuanqiu Bao and Chamberlain Han Anguo advanced to remonstrate with the king, the king then ordered Sheng and Gui both to commit suicide, and handed them out. The emperor from this resented and distrusted the King of Liang. The King of Liang feared, so sent Han Anguo through the eldest princess to apologize to the empress dowager, then was released.

sentences.zh: 上怒稍解，因上書請朝。

translations.literal: The emperor's anger slightly eased, thus he submitted a memorial requesting to attend court.

sentences.zh: 既至關，茅蘭說王，使乘布車，從兩騎入，匿於長公主園。

translations.literal: Having reached the pass, Mao Lan advised the king to ride a cloth carriage, enter following two riders, hide in the eldest princess's garden.

sentences.zh: 漢使使迎王，王已入關，車騎盡居外，不知王處。

translations.literal: Han sent envoys to welcome the king, the king had already entered the pass, chariots and cavalry all stayed outside, did not know the king's location.

sentences.zh: 太后泣曰：「帝殺吾子！」

translations.literal: The empress dowager wept saying: 'The emperor has killed my son!'

sentences.zh: 景帝憂恐。

translations.literal: Emperor Jing was worried and fearful.

sentences.zh: 於是梁王伏斧質於闕下，謝罪，然後太后、景帝大喜，相泣，復如故。

translations.literal: Thus the King of Liang prostrated himself with axe and block at the palace gate, apologized for his crimes, then the empress dowager and Emperor Jing greatly rejoiced, wept together, restored as before.

sentences.zh: 悉召王從官入關。

translations.literal: All summoned the king's following officials into the pass.

sentences.zh: 然景帝益疏王，不同車輦矣。

translations.literal: Yet Emperor Jing increasingly distanced the king, no longer rode in the same chariot.

The emperor's anger slightly eased, thus he submitted a memorial requesting to attend court. Having reached the pass, Mao Lan advised the king to ride a cloth carriage, enter following two riders, hide in the eldest princess's garden. Han sent envoys to welcome the king, the king had already entered the pass, chariots and cavalry all stayed outside, did not know the king's location. The empress dowager wept saying: 'The emperor has killed my son!' Emperor Jing was worried and fearful. Thus the King of Liang prostrated himself with axe and block at the palace gate, apologized for his crimes, then the empress dowager and Emperor Jing greatly rejoiced, wept together, restored as before. All summoned the king's following officials into the pass. Yet Emperor Jing increasingly distanced the king, no longer rode in the same chariot.

sentences.zh: 三十五年冬，復朝。

translations.literal: In year thirty-five, winter, he attended court again.

sentences.zh: 上疏欲留，上弗許。

translations.literal: He submitted a memorial desiring to remain, the emperor did not permit.

sentences.zh: 歸國，意忽忽不樂。

translations.literal: Returned to his fief, his thoughts were melancholy and unhappy.

sentences.zh: 北獵良山，有獻牛，足出背上，孝王惡之。

translations.literal: He hunted north at Liangshan, someone presented a cow whose feet came out its back, Prince Xiao considered it ominous.

sentences.zh: 六月中，病熱，六日卒，謚曰孝王。

translations.literal: In the sixth month, he fell ill with fever, died after six days, posthumous title Prince Xiao.

In year thirty-five, winter, he attended court again. He submitted a memorial desiring to remain, the emperor did not permit. Returned to his fief, his thoughts were melancholy and unhappy. He hunted north at Liangshan, someone presented a cow whose feet came out its back, Prince Xiao considered it ominous. In the sixth month, he fell ill with fever, died after six days, posthumous title Prince Xiao.

sentences.zh: 孝王慈孝，每聞太后病，口不能食，居不安寢，常欲留長安侍太后。

translations.literal: Prince Xiao was filial and kind, whenever he heard the empress dowager was ill, could not eat, lived and slept restlessly, constantly wished to remain in Chang'an serving the empress dowager.

sentences.zh: 太后亦愛之。

translations.literal: The empress dowager also loved him.

sentences.zh: 及聞梁王薨，竇太后哭極哀，不食，曰：「帝果殺吾子！」

translations.literal: When she heard the King of Liang had died, Empress Dowager Dou cried extremely mournfully, did not eat, said: 'The emperor indeed killed my son!'

sentences.zh: 景帝哀懼，不知所為。

translations.literal: Emperor Jing was sorrowful and fearful, did not know what to do.

sentences.zh: 與長公主計之，乃分梁為五國，盡立孝王男五人為王，女五人皆食湯沐邑。

translations.literal: Consulted with the eldest princess, then divided Liang into five kingdoms, all enfeoffing Prince Xiao's five sons as kings, five daughters all received bath and grooming fiefs.

sentences.zh: 於是奏之太后，太后乃說，為帝加壹湌 。

translations.literal: Thus memorialized to the empress dowager, the empress dowager then was pleased, added one extra drink for the emperor.

Prince Xiao was filial and kind, whenever he heard the empress dowager was ill, could not eat, lived and slept restlessly, constantly wished to remain in Chang'an serving the empress dowager. The empress dowager also loved him. When she heard the King of Liang had died, Empress Dowager Dou cried extremely mournfully, did not eat, said: 'The emperor indeed killed my son!' Emperor Jing was sorrowful and fearful, did not know what to do. Consulted with the eldest princess, then divided Liang into five kingdoms, all enfeoffing Prince Xiao's five sons as kings, five daughters all received bath and grooming fiefs. Thus memorialized to the empress dowager, the empress dowager then was pleased, added one extra drink for the emperor.

sentences.zh: 梁孝王長子買為梁王，是為共王；

translations.literal: Prince Xiao's eldest son Mai became King of Liang, this was King Gong;

sentences.zh: 子明為濟川王；

translations.literal: son Ming became King of Jichuan;

sentences.zh: 子彭離為濟東王；

translations.literal: son Pengli became King of Jidong;

sentences.zh: 子定為山陽王；

translations.literal: son Ding became King of Shanyang;

sentences.zh: 子不識為濟陰王。

translations.literal: son Bushi became King of Jiyin.

Prince Xiao's eldest son Mai became King of Liang, this was King Gong; son Ming became King of Jichuan; son Pengli became King of Jidong; son Ding became King of Shanyang; son Bushi became King of Jiyin.

sentences.zh: 孝王未死時，財以巨萬計，不可勝數。

translations.literal: Before Prince Xiao died, his wealth was counted in millions, beyond numbering.

sentences.zh: 及死，藏府餘黃金尚四十餘萬斤，他財物稱是。

translations.literal: When he died, the treasury still had over 400,000 jin of yellow gold remaining, other valuables matched this.
Before Prince Xiao died, his wealth was counted in millions, beyond numbering. When he died, the treasury still had over 400,000 jin of yellow gold remaining, other valuables matched this.

sentences.zh: 梁共王三年，景帝崩。

translations.literal: In Liang King Gong's third year, Emperor Jing passed away.

sentences.zh: 共王立七年卒，子襄立，是為平王。

translations.literal: King Gong reigned seven years and died, his son Xiang succeeded him, becoming King Ping.
In Liang King Gong's third year, Emperor Jing passed away. King Gong reigned seven years and died, his son Xiang succeeded him, becoming King Ping.

sentences.zh: 梁平王襄十四年，母曰陳太后。

translations.literal: Liang King Ping Xiang's fourteenth year, his mother was called Empress Dowager Chen.

sentences.zh: 共王母曰李太后。

translations.literal: King Gong's mother was called Empress Dowager Li.

sentences.zh: 李太后，親平王之大母也。

translations.literal: Empress Dowager Li was King Ping's paternal grandmother.

sentences.zh: 而平王之后姓任，曰任王后。

translations.literal: And King Ping's queen was surnamed Ren, called Queen Ren.

sentences.zh: 任王后甚有寵於平王襄。

translations.literal: Queen Ren was greatly favored by King Ping Xiang.

sentences.zh: 初，孝王在時，有罍樽，直千金。

translations.literal: Initially, when Prince Xiao was alive, there was a lei zun vessel, worth a thousand jin.

sentences.zh: 孝王誡後世，善保罍樽，無得以與人。

translations.literal: Prince Xiao admonished later generations to carefully preserve the lei zun, not to give it to anyone.

sentences.zh: 任王后聞而欲得罍樽。

translations.literal: Queen Ren heard and desired to obtain the lei zun.

sentences.zh: 平王大母李太后曰：「先王有命，無得以罍樽與人。

translations.literal: King Ping's paternal grandmother Empress Dowager Li said: 'The former king had commands, not to give the lei zun to anyone.

sentences.zh: 他物雖百巨萬，猶自恣也。」

translations.literal: Other things though a hundred million, still at your own discretion.'

sentences.zh: 任王后絕欲得之。

translations.literal: Queen Ren absolutely desired to obtain it.

sentences.zh: 平王襄直使人開府取罍樽，賜任王后。

translations.literal: King Ping Xiang directly sent men to open the treasury and take the lei zun, granting it to Queen Ren.

sentences.zh: 李太后大怒，漢使者來，欲自言，平王襄及任王后遮止，閉門，李太后與爭門，措指，遂不得見漢使者。

translations.literal: Empress Dowager Li greatly angered, Han envoys came, wished to speak herself, King Ping Xiang and Queen Ren blocked and stopped her, closed the gate, Empress Dowager Li contended at the gate, pointed and cursed, thus could not see the Han envoys.

sentences.zh: 李太后亦私與食官長及郎中尹霸等士通亂，而王與任王后以此使人風止李太后，李太后內有淫行，亦已。

translations.literal: Empress Dowager Li also privately had illicit relations with the food official chief and Gentleman-in-Attendance Yin Ba and other scholars, while the king and Queen Ren used this to send people to warn and stop Empress Dowager Li, Empress Dowager Li internally had lewd conduct, and that was all.

sentences.zh: 後病薨。

translations.literal: Later she fell ill and died.

sentences.zh: 病時，任后未嘗請病；

translations.literal: When ill, Queen Ren never inquired about the illness;

sentences.zh: 薨，又不持喪。

translations.literal: When she died, moreover did not observe mourning.

Liang King Ping Xiang's fourteenth year, his mother was called Empress Dowager Chen. King Gong's mother was called Empress Dowager Li. Empress Dowager Li was King Ping's paternal grandmother. And King Ping's queen was surnamed Ren, called Queen Ren. Queen Ren was greatly favored by King Ping Xiang. Initially, when Prince Xiao was alive, there was a lei zun vessel, worth a thousand jin. Prince Xiao admonished later generations to carefully preserve the lei zun, not to give it to anyone. Queen Ren heard and desired to obtain the lei zun. King Ping's paternal grandmother Empress Dowager Li said: 'The former king had commands, not to give the lei zun to anyone. Other things though a hundred million, still at your own discretion.' Queen Ren absolutely desired to obtain it. King Ping Xiang directly sent men to open the treasury and take the lei zun, granting it to Queen Ren. Empress Dowager Li greatly angered, Han envoys came, wished to speak herself, King Ping Xiang and Queen Ren blocked and stopped her, closed the gate, Empress Dowager Li contended at the gate, pointed and cursed, thus could not see the Han envoys. Empress Dowager Li also privately had illicit relations with the food official chief and Gentleman-in-Attendance Yin Ba and other scholars, while the king and Queen Ren used this to send people to warn and stop Empress Dowager Li, Empress Dowager Li internally had lewd conduct, and that was all. Later she fell ill and died. When ill, Queen Ren never inquired about the illness; When she died, moreover did not observe mourning.

sentences.zh: 元朔中，睢陽人類犴反者，人有辱其父，而與淮陽太守客出同車。

translations.literal: In Yuanshuo period, among Suiyang people there was one Lei Qian who was rebellious, someone had insulted his father, and he went out in the same carriage as the Huaiyang governor's guest.

sentences.zh: 太守客出下車，類犴反殺其仇於車上而去。

translations.literal: The governor's guest got out and descended from the carriage, Lei Qian stabbed and killed his enemy on the carriage and left.

sentences.zh: 淮陽太守怒，以讓梁二千石。

translations.literal: The Huaiyang governor angered, rebuked Liang's two thousand shi officials.

sentences.zh: 二千石以下求反甚急，執反親戚。

translations.literal: The two thousand shi officials and below sought the rebel very urgently, arrested the rebel's relatives.

sentences.zh: 反知國陰事，乃上變事，具告知王與大母爭樽狀。

translations.literal: The rebel knew the state's secret matters, thus reported the irregularity, fully informed of the king and paternal grandmother contending over the zun vessel situation.

sentences.zh: 時丞相以下見知之，欲以傷梁長吏，其書聞天子。

translations.literal: At the time the chancellor and below saw and knew it, wished to harm Liang's senior officials, the memorial reached the Son of Heaven.

sentences.zh: 天子下吏驗問，有之。

translations.literal: The Son of Heaven sent officials to investigate and question, it was true.

sentences.zh: 公卿請廢襄為庶人。

translations.literal: The dukes and ministers requested to depose Xiang as commoner.

sentences.zh: 天子曰：「李太后有淫行，而梁王襄無良師傅，故陷不義。」

translations.literal: The Son of Heaven said: 'Empress Dowager Li had lewd conduct, and Liang King Xiang had no good tutors, thus fell into unrighteousness.'

sentences.zh: 乃削梁八城，梟任王后首于市。

translations.literal: Thus he cut away eight Liang cities, beheaded Queen Ren in the market.

sentences.zh: 梁餘尚有十城。

translations.literal: Liang still had ten cities remaining.

sentences.zh: 襄立三十九年卒，謚為平王。

translations.literal: Xiang reigned thirty-nine years and died, posthumous title King Ping.

sentences.zh: 子無傷立為梁王也。

translations.literal: His son Wushang succeeded as King of Liang.

In Yuanshuo period, among Suiyang people there was one Lei Qian who was rebellious, someone had insulted his father, and he went out in the same carriage as the Huaiyang governor's guest. The governor's guest got out and descended from the carriage, Lei Qian stabbed and killed his enemy on the carriage and left. The Huaiyang governor angered, rebuked Liang's two thousand shi officials. The two thousand shi officials and below sought the rebel very urgently, arrested the rebel's relatives. The rebel knew the state's secret matters, thus reported the irregularity, fully informed of the king and paternal grandmother contending over the zun vessel situation. At the time the chancellor and below saw and knew it, wished to harm Liang's senior officials, the memorial reached the Son of Heaven. The Son of Heaven sent officials to investigate and question, it was true. The dukes and ministers requested to depose Xiang as commoner. The Son of Heaven said: 'Empress Dowager Li had lewd conduct, and Liang King Xiang had no good tutors, thus fell into unrighteousness.' Thus he cut away eight Liang cities, beheaded Queen Ren in the market. Liang still had ten cities remaining. Xiang reigned thirty-nine years and died, posthumous title King Ping. His son Wushang succeeded as King of Liang.

sentences.zh: 濟川王明者，梁孝王子，以桓邑侯孝景中六年為濟川王。

translations.literal: King Ming of Jichuan was Prince Xiao's son, as Marquis of Huanyi in Xiaojing middle year 6 became King of Jichuan.

sentences.zh: 七歲，坐射殺其中尉，漢有司請誅，天子弗忍誅，廢明為庶人。

translations.literal: Seven years, because he shot and killed his commandery lieutenant, Han officials requested execution, the Son of Heaven could not bear to execute, deposed Ming as commoner.

sentences.zh: 遷房陵，地入于漢為郡。

translations.literal: Relocated to Fangling, the land entered Han as a commandery.

King Ming of Jichuan was Prince Xiao's son, as Marquis of Huanyi in Xiaojing middle year 6 became King of Jichuan. Seven years, because he shot and killed his commandery lieutenant, Han officials requested execution, the Son of Heaven could not bear to execute, deposed Ming as commoner. Relocated to Fangling, the land entered Han as a commandery.

sentences.zh: 濟東王彭離者，梁孝王子，以孝景中六年為濟東王。

translations.literal: King Pengli of Jidong was Prince Xiao's son, in Xiaojing middle year 6 became King of Jidong.

sentences.zh: 二十九年，彭離驕悍，無人君禮，昏暮私與其奴、亡命少年數十人行剽殺人，取財物以為好。

translations.literal: Twenty-nine years, Pengli was arrogant and fierce, without ruler's ritual, at dusk privately went with his slaves and fugitive youths several dozen people to plunder and kill people, taking wealth as pleasure.

sentences.zh: 所殺發覺者百餘人，國皆知之，莫敢夜行。

translations.literal: Those killed and discovered were over a hundred people, the kingdom all knew it, none dared travel at night.

sentences.zh: 所殺者子上書言。

translations.literal: The one killed submitted a memorial to report.

sentences.zh: 漢有司請誅，上不忍，廢以為庶人，遷上庸，地入于漢，為大河郡。

translations.literal: Han officials requested execution, the emperor could not bear it, deposed as commoner, relocated to Shangyong, land entered Han, became Dahe commandery.

King Pengli of Jidong was Prince Xiao's son, in Xiaojing middle year 6 became King of Jidong. Twenty-nine years, Pengli was arrogant and fierce, without ruler's ritual, at dusk privately went with his slaves and fugitive youths several dozen people to plunder and kill people, taking wealth as pleasure. Those killed and discovered were over a hundred people, the kingdom all knew it, none dared travel at night. The one killed submitted a memorial to report. Han officials requested execution, the emperor could not bear it, deposed as commoner, relocated to Shangyong, land entered Han, became Dahe commandery.

sentences.zh: 山陽哀王定者，梁孝王子，以孝景中六年為山陽王。

translations.literal: King Ai Ding of Shanyang was Prince Xiao's son, in Xiaojing middle year 6 became King of Shanyang.

sentences.zh: 九年卒，無子，國除，地入于漢，為山陽郡。

translations.literal: Nine years died, no son, kingdom abolished, land entered Han, became Shanyang commandery.
King Ai Ding of Shanyang was Prince Xiao's son, in Xiaojing middle year 6 became King of Shanyang. Nine years died, no son, kingdom abolished, land entered Han, became Shanyang commandery.

sentences.zh: 濟陰哀王不識者，梁孝王子，以孝景中六年為濟陰王。

translations.literal: King Ai Bushi of Jiyin was Prince Xiao's son, in Xiaojing middle year 6 became King of Jiyin.

sentences.zh: 一歲卒，無子，國除，地入于漢，為濟陰郡。

translations.literal: One year died, no son, kingdom abolished, land entered Han, became Jiyin commandery.
King Ai Bushi of Jiyin was Prince Xiao's son, in Xiaojing middle year 6 became King of Jiyin. One year died, no son, kingdom abolished, land entered Han, became Jiyin commandery.

sentences.zh: 太史公曰：梁孝王雖以親愛之故，王膏腴之地，然會漢家隆盛，百姓殷富，故能植其財貨，廣宮室，車服擬於天子。

translations.literal: The Grand Historian says: Though Prince Xiao of Liang because of close affection was enfeoffed with fertile lands, yet meeting when the Han house was flourishing, people wealthy, thus could accumulate his wealth, expand palaces, carriages and robes comparable to the Son of Heaven.

sentences.zh: 然亦僭矣。

translations.literal: Yet it was also presumptuous.

The Grand Historian says: Though Prince Xiao of Liang because of close affection was enfeoffed with fertile lands, yet meeting when the Han house was flourishing, people wealthy, thus could accumulate his wealth, expand palaces, carriages and robes comparable to the Son of Heaven. Yet it was also presumptuous.

sentences.zh: 褚先生曰：臣為郎時，聞之於宮殿中老郎吏好事者稱道之也。

translations.literal: Master Chu says: When your servant was a gentleman, heard it from old gentleman officials in the palace halls who liked history relating it.

sentences.zh: 竊以為令梁孝王怨望，欲為不善者，事從中生。

translations.literal: I privately consider that causing Prince Xiao of Liang to resent and wish to do evil, the matter arose from within.

sentences.zh: 今太后，女主也，以愛少子故，欲令梁王為太子。

translations.literal: Now the empress dowager is a female ruler, because she loved the youngest son, wished to make the King of Liang crown prince.

sentences.zh: 大臣不時正言其不可狀，阿意治小，私說意以受賞賜，非忠臣也。

translations.literal: Ministers did not timely correctly speak of the impropriety, flattered and handled trifles, privately spoke pleasing words to receive rewards and grants, not loyal ministers.

sentences.zh: 齊如魏其侯竇嬰之正言也，何以有後禍？

translations.literal: How like Marquis Weiqi Dou Ying's correct speech—what future calamity would there be?

sentences.zh: 景帝與王燕見，侍太后飲，景帝曰：「千秋萬歲之後傳王。」

translations.literal: Emperor Jing and the king met in banquet, serving the empress dowager drinking, Emperor Jing said: 'After a thousand autumns and ten thousand years I will pass it to the king.'

sentences.zh: 太后喜說。

translations.literal: The empress dowager was pleased and happy.

sentences.zh: 竇嬰在前，據地言曰：「漢法之約，傳子適孫，今帝何以得傳弟，擅亂高帝約乎！」

translations.literal: Dou Ying was in front, struck the ground and said: 'The Han law's covenant is to pass to son and grandson, now how can the emperor pass to younger brother, arbitrarily disrupt Gaozu's covenant!'

sentences.zh: 於是景帝默然無聲。

translations.literal: Thus Emperor Jing was silent without sound.

sentences.zh: 太后意不說。

translations.literal: The empress dowager's intent was displeased.

Master Chu says: When your servant was a gentleman, heard it from old gentleman officials in the palace halls who liked history relating it. I privately consider that causing Prince Xiao of Liang to resent and wish to do evil, the matter arose from within. Now the empress dowager is a female ruler, because she loved the youngest son, wished to make the King of Liang crown prince. Ministers did not timely correctly speak of the impropriety, flattered and handled trifles, privately spoke pleasing words to receive rewards and grants, not loyal ministers. How like Marquis Weiqi Dou Ying's correct speech—what future calamity would there be? Emperor Jing and the king met in banquet, serving the empress dowager drinking, Emperor Jing said: 'After a thousand autumns and ten thousand years I will pass it to the king.' The empress dowager was pleased and happy. Dou Ying was in front, struck the ground and said: 'The Han law's covenant is to pass to son and grandson, now how can the emperor pass to younger brother, arbitrarily disrupt Gaozu's covenant!' Thus Emperor Jing was silent without sound. The empress dowager's intent was displeased.

sentences.zh: 故成王與小弱弟立樹下，取一桐葉以與之，曰：「吾用封汝。」

translations.literal: Thus King Cheng stood with his young weak brother under a tree, took one paulownia leaf and gave it to him, saying: 'I will use this to enfeoff you.'

sentences.zh: 周公聞之，進見曰：「天王封弟，甚善。」

translations.literal: The Duke of Zhou heard it, advanced and saw saying: 'The Heavenly King enfeoffs his younger brother, very good.'

sentences.zh: 成王曰：「吾直與戲耳。」

translations.literal: King Cheng said: 'I was just playing with him.'

sentences.zh: 周公曰：「人主無過舉，不當有戲言，言之必行之。」

translations.literal: The Duke of Zhou said: 'A ruler has no erroneous actions, should not have joking words—words spoken must be carried out.'

sentences.zh: 於是乃封小弟以應縣。

translations.literal: Thus he enfeoffed the young brother with Ying county.

sentences.zh: 是後成王沒齒不敢有戲言，言必行之。

translations.literal: After this King Cheng to the end of his life dared not have joking words, words spoken must be carried out.

sentences.zh: 《孝經》曰：「非法不言，非道不行。」

translations.literal: The Classic of Filial Piety says: 'Do not speak what is not according to law, do not act what is not according to the Way.'

sentences.zh: 此聖人之法言也。

translations.literal: This is the legal words of the sages.

sentences.zh: 今主上不宜出好言於梁王。

translations.literal: Now the sovereign should not speak favorable words to the King of Liang.

sentences.zh: 梁王上有太后之重，驕蹇日久，數聞景帝好言，千秋萬世之後傳王，而實不行。

translations.literal: The King of Liang above has the empress dowager's weight, arrogant and willful for a long time, repeatedly heard Emperor Jing's favorable words that after a thousand autumns and ten thousand years he would pass to the king, yet in reality not carried out.

Thus King Cheng stood with his young weak brother under a tree, took one paulownia leaf and gave it to him, saying: 'I will use this to enfeoff you.' The Duke of Zhou heard it, advanced and saw saying: 'The Heavenly King enfeoffs his younger brother, very good.' King Cheng said: 'I was just playing with him.' The Duke of Zhou said: 'A ruler has no erroneous actions, should not have joking words—words spoken must be carried out.' Thus he enfeoffed the young brother with Ying county. After this King Cheng to the end of his life dared not have joking words, words spoken must be carried out. The Classic of Filial Piety says: 'Do not speak what is not according to law, do not act what is not according to the Way.' This is the legal words of the sages. Now the sovereign should not speak favorable words to the King of Liang. The King of Liang above has the empress dowager's weight, arrogant and willful for a long time, repeatedly heard Emperor Jing's favorable words that after a thousand autumns and ten thousand years he would pass to the king, yet in reality not carried out.

sentences.zh: 又諸侯王朝見天子，漢法凡當四見耳。

translations.literal: Moreover feudal lords' kings attending court to see the Son of Heaven, Han law generally should be four audiences.

sentences.zh: 始到，入小見；

translations.literal: First arrival, enter for small audience;

sentences.zh: 到正月朔旦，奉皮薦璧玉賀正月，法見；

translations.literal: Arrive at New Year's first dawn, present leather and recommend jade discs to congratulate New Year, formal audience;

sentences.zh: 後三日，為王置酒，賜金錢財物；

translations.literal: Three days later, set wine for the king, grant gold money and valuables;

sentences.zh: 後二日，復入小見，辭去。

translations.literal: Two days later, again enter for small audience, take leave and depart.

sentences.zh: 凡留長安不過二十日。

translations.literal: Altogether remaining in Chang'an not over twenty days.

sentences.zh: 小見者，燕見於禁門內，飲於省中，非士人所得入也。

translations.literal: Small audience means banquet meeting within the forbidden gates, drinking in the administration quarters, not where scholars can enter.

sentences.zh: 今梁王西朝，因留，且半歲。

translations.literal: Now the King of Liang comes west to court, thus stays, nearly half a year.

sentences.zh: 入與人主同輦，出與同車。

translations.literal: He shared the ruler's chariot when entering court, and his carriage when leaving.

sentences.zh: 示風以大言而實不與，令出怨言，謀畔逆，乃隨而憂之，不亦遠乎！

translations.literal: Shows a precedent with great words yet in reality does not give, causes resentful words to come out, plots rebellion and reversal, then follows to worry about it—isn't this far-reaching!

sentences.zh: 非大賢人，不知退讓。

translations.literal: If not a great worthy person, does not know yielding and retreating.

sentences.zh: 今漢之儀法，朝見賀正月者，常一王與四侯俱朝見，十餘歲一至。

translations.literal: Now Han's ritual law, those attending court and congratulating New Year, normally one king with four marquises together attend court, once every ten or more years.

sentences.zh: 今梁王常比年入朝見，久留。

translations.literal: Now the King of Liang constantly attends court consecutively, stays long.

sentences.zh: 鄙語曰「驕子不孝」，非惡言也。

translations.literal: The vulgar saying goes 'spoiled son is unfilial', not evil words.

sentences.zh: 故諸侯王當為置良師傅，相忠言之士，如汲黯、韓長孺等，敢直言極諫，安得有患害！

translations.literal: Therefore feudal kings should be given good tutors and chancellors, loyal speaking officials, like Ji An, Han Changru and such, who dare to speak directly and remonstrate extremely—how can there be calamity and harm!

Moreover feudal lords' kings attending court to see the Son of Heaven, Han law generally should be four audiences. First arrival, enter for small audience; Arrive at New Year's first dawn, present leather and recommend jade discs to congratulate New Year, formal audience; Three days later, set wine for the king, grant gold money and valuables; Two days later, again enter for small audience, take leave and depart. Altogether remaining in Chang'an not over twenty days. Small audience means banquet meeting within the forbidden gates, drinking in the administration quarters, not where scholars can enter. Now the King of Liang comes west to court, thus stays, nearly half a year. He shared the ruler's chariot when entering court, and his carriage when leaving. Shows a precedent with great words yet in reality does not give, causes resentful words to come out, plots rebellion and reversal, then follows to worry about it—isn't this far-reaching! If not a great worthy person, does not know yielding and retreating. Now Han's ritual law, those attending court and congratulating New Year, normally one king with four marquises together attend court, once every ten or more years. Now the King of Liang constantly attends court consecutively, stays long. The vulgar saying goes 'spoiled son is unfilial', not evil words. Therefore feudal kings should be given good tutors and chancellors, loyal speaking officials, like Ji An, Han Changru and such, who dare to speak directly and remonstrate extremely—how can there be calamity and harm!

sentences.zh: 蓋聞梁王西入朝，謁竇太后，燕見，與景帝俱侍坐於太后前，語言私說。

translations.literal: I heard that the King of Liang entered west to court, greeted Empress Dowager Dou, banquet meeting, together with Emperor Jing served and sat before the empress dowager, private language pleased.

sentences.zh: 太后謂帝曰：「吾聞殷道親親，周道尊尊，其義一也。

translations.literal: The empress dowager told the emperor: 'I heard Yin way loves relatives, Zhou way honors superiors, their meanings are one.

sentences.zh: 安車大駕，用梁孝王為寄。」

translations.literal: Peaceful carriage great procession, use Prince Xiao of Liang as the heir.'

sentences.zh: 景帝跪席舉身曰：「諾。」

translations.literal: Emperor Jing knelt on the mat and raised his body saying: 'Yes.'

sentences.zh: 罷酒出，帝召袁盎諸大臣通經術者曰：「太后言如是，何謂也？」

translations.literal: Finished the wine and went out, the emperor summoned Yuan Ang and various ministers versed in classics saying: 'The empress dowager speaks like this, what does it mean?'

sentences.zh: 皆對曰：「太后意欲立梁王為帝太子。」

translations.literal: All replied: 'The empress dowager intends to establish the King of Liang as imperial crown prince.'

sentences.zh: 帝問其狀，袁盎等曰：「殷道親親者，立弟。

translations.literal: The emperor asked the circumstances, Yuan Ang and others said: 'Yin way loves relatives establishes younger brother.

sentences.zh: 周道尊尊者，立子。

translations.literal: Zhou way honors superiors establishes son.

sentences.zh: 殷道質，質者法天，親其所親，故立弟。

translations.literal: Yin way substantial, substantial follows Heaven, loves those close to it, thus establishes younger brother.

sentences.zh: 周道文，文者法地，尊者敬也，敬其本始，故立長子。

translations.literal: Zhou way cultured, cultured follows Earth, honor means respect, respects its origin, thus establishes eldest son.

sentences.zh: 周道，太子死，立適孫。

translations.literal: Zhou way, crown prince dies, establishes proper grandson.

sentences.zh: 殷道。

translations.literal: Yin way.

sentences.zh: 太子死，立其弟。」

translations.literal: Crown prince dies, establishes his younger brother.'

sentences.zh: 帝曰：「於公何如？」

translations.literal: The emperor said: 'To you gentlemen what is it?'

sentences.zh: 皆對曰：「方今漢家法周，周道不得立弟，當立子。

translations.literal: All replied: 'Now the Han house follows Zhou, Zhou way cannot establish younger brother, should establish son.

sentences.zh: 故春秋所以非宋宣公。

translations.literal: Therefore the Spring and Autumn Annals criticizes Duke Xuan of Song.

sentences.zh: 宋宣公死，不立子而與弟。

translations.literal: Duke Xuan of Song died, did not establish son but gave to younger brother.

sentences.zh: 弟受國死，復反之與兄之子。

translations.literal: Younger brother received the state died, again returned it to elder brother's son.

sentences.zh: 弟之子爭之，以為我當代父後，即刺殺兄子。

translations.literal: Younger brother's son contended for it, considering I should succeed father's place, thus stabbed and killed elder brother's son.

sentences.zh: 以故國亂，禍不絕。

translations.literal: Therefore the state was chaotic, calamities did not cease.

sentences.zh: 故春秋曰『君子大居正，宋之禍宣公為之』。

translations.literal: Therefore the Spring and Autumn Annals says 'The gentleman greatly occupies correctness, Song's calamity Duke Xuan made it.'

sentences.zh: 臣請見太后白之。」

translations.literal: Your servants request to see the empress dowager and inform her.'

sentences.zh: 袁盎等入見太后：「太后言欲立梁王，梁王即終，欲誰立？」

translations.literal: Yuan Ang and others entered to see the empress dowager: 'The empress dowager speaks wishing to establish the King of Liang, if the King of Liang should die, wishes to establish whom?'

sentences.zh: 太后曰：「吾復立帝子。」

translations.literal: The empress dowager said: 'I will again establish the emperor's son.'

sentences.zh: 袁盎等以宋宣公不立正，生禍，禍亂後五世不絕，小不忍害大義狀報太后。

translations.literal: Yuan Ang and others with Duke Xuan of Song not establishing properly, produced calamity, calamity and chaos after five generations not ceased, little intolerance harming great righteousness, reported to the empress dowager.

sentences.zh: 太后乃解說，即使梁王歸就國。

translations.literal: The empress dowager then dispelled her idea, immediately had the King of Liang return to his fief.

sentences.zh: 而梁王聞其義出於袁盎諸大臣所，怨望，使人來殺袁盎。

translations.literal: And the King of Liang heard that the righteousness came from Yuan Ang and the various ministers, resented, sent men to come kill Yuan Ang.

sentences.zh: 袁盎顧之曰：「我所謂袁將軍者也，公得毋誤乎？」

translations.literal: Yuan Ang looked at him saying: 'The one called General Yuan is me, sir has not mistaken?'

sentences.zh: 刺者曰：「是矣！」

translations.literal: The assassin said: 'Correct!'

sentences.zh: 刺之，置其劍，劍著身。

translations.literal: Stabbed him, left his sword, the sword stuck in the body.

sentences.zh: 視其劍，新治。

translations.literal: Looked at his sword, newly forged.

sentences.zh: 問長安中削厲工，工曰：「梁郎某子來治此劍。」

translations.literal: Asked Chang'an's sword sharpening workers, the worker said: 'A Liang attendant some son came to forge this sword.'

sentences.zh: 以此知而發覺之，發使者捕逐之。

translations.literal: With this knew and discovered it, sent envoys to capture and pursue them.

sentences.zh: 獨梁王所欲殺大臣十餘人，文吏窮本之，謀反端頗見。

translations.literal: Only the King of Liang desired to kill ministers more than ten, the civil officials investigated to the root, rebellion signs much appeared.

sentences.zh: 太后不食，日夜泣不止。

translations.literal: The empress dowager did not eat, day and night wept without stopping.

sentences.zh: 景帝甚憂之，問公卿大臣，大臣以為遣經術吏往治之，乃可解。

translations.literal: Emperor Jing greatly worried about it, asked the dukes and ministers, ministers considered sending classic versed officials to handle it, then could resolve.

sentences.zh: 於是遣田叔、呂季主往治之。

translations.literal: Thus sent Tian Shu, Lu Jizhu to handle it.

sentences.zh: 此二人皆通經術，知大禮。

translations.literal: These two both versed in classics, knew great ritual.

sentences.zh: 來還，至霸昌廄，取火悉燒梁之反辭，但空手來對景帝。

translations.literal: Coming back, arrived at Bachang stable, took fire and completely burned Liang's rebellion documents, but came with empty hands to answer Emperor Jing.

sentences.zh: 景帝曰：「何如？」

translations.literal: Emperor Jing said: 'What is it like?'

sentences.zh: 對曰：「言梁王不知也。

translations.literal: Replied: 'Says the King of Liang did not know.

sentences.zh: 造為之者，獨其幸臣羊勝、公孫詭之屬為之耳。

translations.literal: Those who fabricated it were only his favored ministers Yang Sheng, Gongsun Gui and such did it.

sentences.zh: 謹以伏誅死，梁王無恙也。」

translations.literal: Respectfully they should be executed by law, the King of Liang is fine.'

sentences.zh: 景帝喜說，曰：「急趨謁太后。」

translations.literal: Emperor Jing pleased and happy, said: 'Quickly go announce to the empress dowager.'

sentences.zh: 太后聞之，立起坐湌，氣平復。

translations.literal: The empress dowager heard it, immediately rose and sat drinking, her energy calmed and recovered.

sentences.zh: 故曰，不通經術知古今之大禮，不可以為三公及左右近臣。

translations.literal: Therefore it is said, if not versed in classics and knowing ancient and modern great ritual, cannot serve as three dukes and left and right close ministers.

sentences.zh: 少見之人，如從管中闚天也。

translations.literal: People of little knowledge are like peeking at heaven from a tube.

I heard that the King of Liang entered west to court, greeted Empress Dowager Dou, banquet meeting, together with Emperor Jing served and sat before the empress dowager, private language pleased. The empress dowager told the emperor: 'I heard Yin way loves relatives, Zhou way honors superiors, their meanings are one. Peaceful carriage great procession, use Prince Xiao of Liang as the heir.' Emperor Jing knelt on the mat and raised his body saying: 'Yes.' Finished the wine and went out, the emperor summoned Yuan Ang and various ministers versed in classics saying: 'The empress dowager speaks like this, what does it mean?' All replied: 'The empress dowager intends to establish the King of Liang as imperial crown prince.' The emperor asked the circumstances, Yuan Ang and others said: 'Yin way loves relatives establishes younger brother. Zhou way honors superiors establishes son. Yin way substantial, substantial follows Heaven, loves those close to it, thus establishes younger brother. Zhou way cultured, cultured follows Earth, honor means respect, respects its origin, thus establishes eldest son. Zhou way, crown prince dies, establishes proper grandson. Yin way. Crown prince dies, establishes his younger brother.' The emperor said: 'To you gentlemen what is it?' All replied: 'Now the Han house follows Zhou, Zhou way cannot establish younger brother, should establish son. Therefore the Spring and Autumn Annals criticizes Duke Xuan of Song. Duke Xuan of Song died, did not establish son but gave to younger brother. Younger brother received the state died, again returned it to elder brother's son. Younger brother's son contended for it, considering I should succeed father's place, thus stabbed and killed elder brother's son. Therefore the state was chaotic, calamities did not cease. Therefore the Spring and Autumn Annals says 'The gentleman greatly occupies correctness, Song's calamity Duke Xuan made it.' Your servants request to see the empress dowager and inform her.' Yuan Ang and others entered to see the empress dowager: 'The empress dowager speaks wishing to establish the King of Liang, if the King of Liang should die, wishes to establish whom?' The empress dowager said: 'I will again establish the emperor's son.' Yuan Ang and others with Duke Xuan of Song not establishing properly, produced calamity, calamity and chaos after five generations not ceased, little intolerance harming great righteousness, reported to the empress dowager. The empress dowager then dispelled her idea, immediately had the King of Liang return to his fief. And the King of Liang heard that the righteousness came from Yuan Ang and the various ministers, resented, sent men to come kill Yuan Ang. Yuan Ang looked at him saying: 'The one called General Yuan is me, sir has not mistaken?' The assassin said: 'Correct!' Stabbed him, left his sword, the sword stuck in the body. Looked at his sword, newly forged. Asked Chang'an's sword sharpening workers, the worker said: 'A Liang attendant some son came to forge this sword.' With this knew and discovered it, sent envoys to capture and pursue them. Only the King of Liang desired to kill ministers more than ten, the civil officials investigated to the root, rebellion signs much appeared. The empress dowager did not eat, day and night wept without stopping. Emperor Jing greatly worried about it, asked the dukes and ministers, ministers considered sending classic versed officials to handle it, then could resolve. Thus sent Tian Shu, Lu Jizhu to handle it. These two both versed in classics, knew great ritual. Coming back, arrived at Bachang stable, took fire and completely burned Liang's rebellion documents, but came with empty hands to answer Emperor Jing. Emperor Jing said: 'What is it like?' Replied: 'Says the King of Liang did not know. Those who fabricated it were only his favored ministers Yang Sheng, Gongsun Gui and such did it. Respectfully they should be executed by law, the King of Liang is fine.' Emperor Jing pleased and happy, said: 'Quickly go announce to the empress dowager.' The empress dowager heard it, immediately rose and sat drinking, her energy calmed and recovered. Therefore it is said, if not versed in classics and knowing ancient and modern great ritual, cannot serve as three dukes and left and right close ministers. People of little knowledge are like peeking at heaven from a tube.
